qas.question: What allegation did the government level against The Sun in 2003?
Who specifically leveled the allegations against The Sun?

answers.text: Prime Minister's press spokesman Alastair Campbell and the Home Secretary David Blunkett

qas.question: What did a 4 July 2003 front page story claim?

answers.text: asylum seekers were slaughtering and eating swans

qas.question: From which issue did claims that The Sun was racist stem?
Who did The Sun print pictures of in a Nazi outfit in 2005?

context: In 2003 the paper was accused of <a0_0>racism<a0_0/> by the Government over its criticisms of what it perceived as the "open door" policy on <a3_0>immigration<a3_0/>. The attacks came from the <a1_0>Prime Minister's press spokesman Alastair Campbell and the Home Secretary David Blunkett<a1_0/> (later a Sun columnist). The paper rebutted the claim, believing that it was not racist to suggest that a "tide" of unchecked illegal immigrants was increasing the risk of terrorist attacks and infectious diseases. It did not help its argument by publishing a front page story on 4 July 2003, under the headline "Swan Bake", which claimed that <a2_0>asylum seekers were slaughtering and eating swans<a2_0/>. It later proved to have no basis in fact. Subsequently The Sun published a follow-up headlined "Now they're after our fish!". Following a Press Complaints Commission adjudication a "clarification" was eventually printed, on page 41. In 2005 The Sun published photographs of <a4_0>Prince Harry<a4_0/> sporting a Nazi costume to a fancy dress party. The photographs caused outrage across the world and Clarence House was forced to issue a statement in response apologising for any offence or embarrassment caused.
